snippet: U.S. soldiers accused Afghan police and Navy SEALs of abusing detainees. But the SEAL command opted against a court-martial and cleared its men of wrongdoing.
abstract: Investigation reveals Navy SEALs may have covered up incident in which several SEALs joined with Afghan troops in abusing detainees in May 2012, leading to death of one detainee; abuse of detainees is considered serious offense worthy of court-martial, but SEAL command reportedly cleared members of wrongdoing via internal disciplinary process ordinarily reserved for minor infractions.

byline.original: By NICHOLAS KULISH, CHRISTOPHER DREW and MATTHEW ROSENBERG
byline.contributor: Nicholas Kulish reported from California, Colorado, Georgia and Louisiana; Christopher Drew from Washington, Maryland and Virginia; and Matthew Rosenberg from Kabul, Afghanistan. Mark Mazzetti contributed reporting from Washington, Nooruddin Bakhshi from Kabul and Taimoor Shah from Kandahar, Afghanistan. Kitty Bennett and Susan C. Beachy contributed research.

lead_paragraph: U.S. soldiers accused Afghan police and Navy SEALs of abusing detainees. But the SEAL command opted against a court-martial and cleared its men of wrongdoing.

headline.main: Navy SEALs, a Beating Death and Claims of a Cover-Up
headline.print_headline: Navy SEALs, a Beating Death and Claims of a Cover-Up

keywords.name: subject
keywords.value: United States Defense and Military Forces
